lead_paragraph: Officer Edward M. Nero’s trial in Baltimore renewed questions about when police officers can stop a private citizen and what they are allowed to do.

byline.contributor: Jess Bidgood reported from Baltimore, and Timothy Williams from New York. Nicholas Fandos contributed reporting from Baltimore.
byline.original: By JESS BIDGOOD and TIMOTHY WILLIAMS

headline.print_headline: Baltimore Judge Absolves Officer in Fatal Arrest
headline.main: Police Officer in Freddie Gray Case Is Acquitted of All Charges

snippet: Officer Edward M. Nero’s trial in Baltimore renewed questions about when police officers can stop a private citizen and what they are allowed to do.
abstract: Judge Barry G Williams acquits Baltimore, Md, Police Officer Edward M Nero of all four charges against him in connection with arrest of Freddie Gray, black man who suffered fatal spinal cord injury while in police custody, after defense lawyers prove that Nero never touched Gray during critical moments of his arrest; ruling renews question of whether any of six police officers charged in connection with Gray's death will be convicted.
